number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Magicka proves the statement, that even the strongest basis can prove itself useless at some point. Being an Action-RPG with isometric perspective, Terry Prattchet-esque sense of humour as a selling point and emphasis on cooperative play, that takes place in some fantasy world, surprisingly similiar to what we could see in almost any other fantasy game.  Sounds good? Well, tough ♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Magicka gives a new meaning to the term "frustratingly hard", even when played on easiest difficulty. Mostly because of the control system, that seemingly was made by some mental clinic patient, with severe case of ham-handness.  Some may call this "innovation" but some can also try putting shattered glass and gravel to their bowl of cereal.While the good game usually cannot stand on single-player only, with some exceptions of course, Magicka has also got a nice selection of multiplayer modes. Being a litle interested in deathmatch mode (or whatever kind of gameplay Magicka has to offer instead), i tried playing it in cooperative mode. And it was only slightly less painful than swallowing a bottle of "Jack Daniels" whiskey. What is originaly presented as a coop mode, in the end becomes excruciating cluster-molesting mess that plays as smoothly, as Super Mario on NES, with TV turned upside-down.  Of course, this happens only when you are actually allowed to play, since most of the time network protocol decides to be a total♥♥♥♥♥♥ The main issue with the control system, that it was designed for some alien-like creature. Like any other PC-gamer, i got used to have WASD as movement controls. Frankly, i was unpleasantly surprised, when attempt to move my character with those keys resulted in his/her/it's immidiate and needlessly gory death. Even when i got used to the controls there, i still couldn't fight back properly. And since i've played it in coop mode, i possesed more treat to the other players, than the monsters. Since i've mentioned frustration, that slowly was growing to anger, i cannot leave another deadly sin without mentioning. Greed. Developers of this game really think, that there will be people, willing to spend significant anmount of their disposable income on various robe sets for their protagonists and other DLC's. Needless to say, that majority of DLC's can be called "overpriced", just as Magicka itself "has a couple of pop-culture references". Not that they would cost too much. They just don't worth it. Maybe this game wasn't meant to be serious. I won't question that. But i also won't question that the term "game" means something at least vaguely entertaning to spend time when Magicka utterly fails in this department. If after that someone needs a digital equivalent of my opinion, i'd give it a dead rooster out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												The biggest gripe all my friends have with this game (and why I can never get anyone to play it with me) is that the controls are so much different than any other game out there that you basically have to start over every time you play it.  Combine that with the fact that your character can die in one hit from an enemy spell and you get quite a difficult game.  Also the fact that your "buddies" can (or yourself) set you on fire, douse you with water and then shock you with lightning or simply crush you with a rock, all completely on accident, can add to the difficulty. This game would be unplayable without the fact that in multiplayer your "co-op" buddies can ressurect you very quickly and an infinite number of times; I don't even bother trying to play it single player.There are very few games that put so much power into your hands.  This one does.  All at once.  Right after the tutorial.  There are over 1000 spell combinations that you can cast right out of the starting gate based on what elements you choose to put into your spell and how you cast it (cast forward, cast AOE, cast on self).  Throughout the rest of the game you'll gain access to a handful more spells but you've got 99% of them right when you start.I've played the game several times, starting over to re-learn the controls each time.  Supposedly the base game can be beaten in under 4 hours (for the achievement), but I've never once managed to finish the game.  Between the entire party dying and starting sections over many, many times and just spending time mucking around with magick, beating the entire the game tends to always take longer than my friends have to play it.I think this is a great game, but you have to have someone to play it with.

Posted: August 24, 2011
												This is a good game that falls short of true greatness due to one fault, at least in single player mode. You can't save, and the auto-save points are too far apart. Moreover, the single-player is difficult, so you die often, which requires you to start a part of the game all over again. Other than that, it is great fun, and I suspect the multiplayer is equally engrossing. Very much worth purchasing especially if you don't mind shutting it down for a while to come back later and retry some of the harder parts.  8/10.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Won this game in a giveaway, and I'm really happy I had a chance to play it.If you like magic-based games, being a wizard, combining spells for a multitude of combinations, and fun gameplay, then you will really love this game.The aesthetics are great, the art is very refreshing and detailed, and the effects for the numerous spell combinations is both varied and well-done. The music and sounds are very good and enhance the atmosphere created by the game. The game itself is packed with a wonderful mix of action and comedy - the characters speak a gibberish language (similar to the simspeak in The Sims games). There is also a lot of satire and teasing of common game mechanics throughout your playthrough. You may skip cutscenes, which is very useful if you are doing another playthrough or have died and have to go through some again. The feedback is very informative and helpful, and the mapping of everything is ergonomic so you know where everything is.The story is pretty good and the narration is well-done. The controls are not too complicated and the tutorial (skippable) is quick, fun, and extremely helpful for getting your bearings. The learning curve is minimal to moderate - the most challenging thing will probably be remembering your spell combos and pressing the correct spells accurately and quickly. You have 8 different spells (ex: lightning, life, shield, fire) and can combine them for different effects. Books provide recipes for spells, however, you can also experiment and find out some blueprints of your own. For example, using the shield and life spells will create a semicircle of life proximity mines, which explode and give you a massive boost to health. Using ice and water will give you machinegun-like projectiles. The possiblities are numerous and extremely varied. You can also scroll through your list of acquired spells with the mouse wheel to have the combination available to you for reference without having to go to the Magicka (spells) menu.The gameplay is very fun and not too challenging, however, if you manage to get some friends to play this game with, you will enjoy it immensely.A very fun, refreshing, and charming game. Check it out if you are interested in being a wizard.Highly recommend!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												I got this game because I heard about the the way the spell casting system worked. A friend that I play with says the best way to describe it is, "the player levels up, not the character." The more the player plays, the more they memorize the keystrokes needed to cast the spell they want and their casting speed naturally increases also. Players with an MMO gaming mouse with 12 thumb buttons can also just program macros for the most common spells, but there's a lot of fun n watching your friends miscast their spell and accidentally killing themselves and/or their teammates. What kept me coming back for more is the fact that the main campaign is full of funny pop culture references to Star Wars, Star Trek, Lord of the Rings, Indiana Jones, and many other works of film and television.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Most games give you a challenge by limiting you. Magicka tries to challenge you without doing that (though the DLCs seems to have strayed from that philosophy.) The game gives you powerful spells, no mana and no cooldown to limit your spellcasting, and yet despite it being pretty much god mode in any other game, still manages to keep you challenged and engaged the entire way through.The DLC ups the ante but, imo, detracted from the original theme by limiting the magicka available to you. If you simply want chaotic fun, the original story mode is still your best bet.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Funny. Entertaining. Awesome. There are a lot of words to describe Magicka and I can assure you very few are negative, especially after a sea of patches. It takes itself seriously in that it wants you to have an enjoyable experience but its wholly lighthearted and satisfyingly gruesome. The game throws at you a huge array of possible spell combinations and rewards experimentation (although sometimes it just makes you feel stupid) as well as giving you an myriad of cool spells to work with. It is an easy to use control system and generally fun although years of shooters have turned my fingers against this game on many occasions. For an indie game is doesn't get much better than Magicka and I think many would agree. Give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												Simply put: Amazing game, fun, new game mechanics, lots of creativity as well.Magicka is a game where 8 elements can be combined to make different kinds of spells. The combinations change the type, size and area of effect of the spell. You follow a story full of refrences to popular culture and varing enemies. The different enemies will be weaker to different spells, but due to the combination systems, occasionally the casting of spells can become repetative once you find most effective spell and crusing through your foes. This can easily be overcome by trying to think of different ways yourself to blast them down.Lots of fun DLC as well, and most of couse, online and LOCAL multiplayer, bringing a friend adds to the excitement and hilarity.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2013
												The idea of mixing spells together might sound good on paper, and it works for some games like Lost Magic on DS, but in Magicka it's just a horrible mess.This game's controls are frustrating because you aim AND move with the mouse, so you can't shoot while moving backwards or dodging, and you gotta use QWERASDF (those 8 buttons) to fiddle with the elements. And if you screw up ONE element, well your whole spell is ruined and you'll have to start over the spell, while getting swarmed with enemies.So, here's how it goes. While trying to dodge the fast, jumping enemies with your super slow characer, you gotta aim AND think of combo spells that work together. But watch out, if you use electric spells after using water spells, you'll get hurt, and fire spells are pointless because even if they somehow don't explode in your face, the enemies will catch on fire and jump on you, so you'll burn to death because of your own spells. That means you end up using the same few Rock / Freezing / Healing / Arcane spells because everything else is just a clusterf*ck.Oh, and you can sort of airblast enemies off the map (you gotta charge it though, and it's only  effective against the smaller enemies), but some enemies can also push YOU off the ledges, which is cheap because you have nothing to defend yourself against that, and when you die you gotta wait like 10 seconds on the obnoxious "DEFEATED" screen and then skip the cinematics you already saw. Every single time.So yeah, don't buy this game unless you're drunk with 3 friends.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
 Keep your friends closer and your enemies closer .. unless you can blast them away... or push them towards the edge.. or into a fire wall or just let them drown .  Magicka is all about having fun and imagination. Use the elements provided and kill your enemies .. and friends  Story Magicka got campaign mode : 12 chapters in which you find items and magicks(special kind of spells) . The story is straightforward - world is in danger and you can save it. NPCs treat you as a fodder and make fun of you until you prove how strong you are with your spells. Also game itself make fun of silent protagonists in general. Devs put a lot of different references in the game so you can go and try to hunt them all . Combat Combat feels a bit like ARPG , prepare your weapon, point at the enemy and kill it .. but without the enemy droping any valuable loot. And your weapon is mainly your spells... or a melee weapon you pick from a corpse.. or a machine gun. Spells  Spells is pretty much the only reason you would play this game.You have 2 kinds of spells.Main one is the combination of 5 elements of your choice and then the secondary is magicks found while playing in which you have to pick set elements to make a different kind of skill that isnt part of the basics.But lets start with the first one.You have 10 elements : Water,Fire,Lighting,Earth,Cold,Shield,Arcane,Life,Ice(combination of water + Cold) , Steam ( Fire + Water). You need to have in mind that some elements are opposite to others and they cant coexist in your spell.Another thing to have in mind: each element got its own form so you have to pick carefuly how to create your spell.And last but not least you have 2 ways to cast the spell, either on yourself or somewhere on the screen.Magicks on the other hand got a set elements and form . Some of them affect only specific ... targets like sprint,revive,teleport while others affect the whole screen like Blizzard or Meteor Shower. Now some of the spells are kinda complicated to learn them fast so you might better off writing down somewhere the combination of key presses so you can cast them faster.Another thing worth noticing is that you can be affected by different elements like you can get wet and when you are wet you cant use lighting and if you try to do so you gonna take dmg. You can be wet, "iced" or set on fire and in order to remove those you need to cast the opposite element on yourself so... have fun !  Co-op While Solo play is fun, co-op is even better ... because of the moments "Sorry, I didnt mean to blast you THAT far ." During co-op there is friendly fire... or more like of insta dead in some cases. While in co-op you can cross beams (ghostbusters anybody?) for stronger effect.. unless you are using opposite elements which lead to someone dying.Teamwork is a must if you want to deal with enemies faster than usual. One thing worth noticing for co-op is that there is no split screen even if you play online Boss Fights The game over a bunch of boss fights which usually requires you to think about what is the opposite element of the boss itself though often several elements will hurting him, there is one that do more damage than the rest. Also have in mind that part of bosses got 1shot skills so .. be careful !!!  Overall Its quite enjoyable game for what is worth and co-op is one of the funniest I played so far. Though solo play is good I suggest you to go for co-op only.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												  Seems like a cool concept for a game, but unfortunately the sole reason why I bought it does not function at all.  A friend and I purchased this together long ago with the intent of playing through the co-op mode, but the game freezes at the same point of the tutorial every time. Skipping by this doesn't seem to help. Others don't seem to be having the same problem, but I'd say if you purchase, do so with the intent to enjoy the singleplayer first. The game is still very buggy and prone to strange problems that might not have a fix.  Aside from that, probably the worst thing about it are the memes and referential humor, which exist throughout the game. If you don't like crap like that and you're intent on picking this up, then prepare to groan.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												This review is written in Bahasa. English version is written below.Magicka adalah game aksi dengan mekanisme sihir elemen yang cukup asyik dengan tampilan gameplay yang mirip DotA. Tugasmu dalam game ini cukup simpel, yaitu hancurkan monster-monster dengan kekuatan sihirmu, kalahkan boss, dan selesaikan setiap stage yang ada. Yang paling menarik dari game ini adalah mekanisme magic-nya, di mana kamu dapat menggabung-gabungkan 8 elemen sihir yang ada untuk menciptakan sihir yang kuat sesuai situasi dan selera--simpel sekaligus kompleks. Ditambah mekanisme MP/mana tak terbatas, kamu bisa merasakan menjadi penyihir yang kuat.Cerita Magicka--yang sedari awal sudah konyol, banyak dibumbui parodi ikon pop culture seperti Star Wars, 300, Castlevania, The Hobbit plus bahasa lucu (English+Swedish+gibberish) sehingga menjadikannya semakin konyol lagi.Sangat menyenangkan untuk dimainkan sendiri ataupun multiplayer (biar bisa saling bunuh antar teman). Oh ya, ingat-ingatlah mantra sakti 'QFASA' dan kalau suntuk jangan lupa 'dunka dunka'. Happy gaming!English VersionMagicka is an action game with interesting elemental magic mechanism, with gameplay which looks similar to DotA. The objective is fairly simple: defeat your enemies with your mighty magick power, defeat the boss and clear the stage. The most interesting thing about this game is its magic casting mechanism where you can combine the 8 magick elements to produce many kinds of spell best suited to the situation and your personal taste. With unlimited MP/mana, you can truly experience what it feels like to be mighty wizard in fantasy RPG setting (with comedic touch).The story--which is already funny, is made even funnier with pop culture icon parodies such as Star Wars, 300, Castlevania, The Hobbit, etc. The Simlish-like language (or maybe English+Swedish+Gibberish) is also very funny.It's a very fun game to play alone or with friends (so you can kill each other 'accidentally'). Also, never forget QFASA and try to do some 'dunka dunka' whenever you get stressed. Happy gaming!

content:
Posted: April 13
												Okay; so, I love this game and I think it's hilarious. I got it on sale, and I have enjoyed it well over the normal price of ten bucks. This game, like a lot of the other reviews are saying, is better with friends. It's also incredibly difficult in singleplayer at times as if you die, you restart kind of thing. I thought the game's best parts were at the first few chapters, and then my experience slowly degraded from there. The fights went from fun and unqiue to just kind of frustratingly hard enemies being thrown at you for the whole stage/area thing. In the first half of the game, the game has really casual-type gameplay, with you not really being punished (Note, I am not saying these chapters because you don't get punished) and you being able to cast new, creative types of magick and just messing around. However, shortly after, the game just expects you to know all of the best castings, so it's very linear and repetitive from there. And, after a while, you'll eventually figure out some of the absolutely broken castings (Such as the "steam-beam-supreme", (I had the displeasure of being a part of the naming process with my friend) which does incredibly high damage per second) and just eliminates all of the creativity of casting spells. Some of the magicks (Lightning Bolt comes to mind) are also incredibly powerful and spam-able; they're all you really need for the whole game. I also got kind of bored after beating this game, but I generally do that with games, so it doesn't really count. It may also be because I logged ~60 hours in the week.TL;DR, very fun, worse singleplayer, bad fights, creativity diminishes after roughly halfway through.
